all_paragraphs: This piece discusses the connection between classical “Ridge Regression” and Bayesian Inference, and how under certain conditions regularization in a Frequentist context is similar to specifying priors in a Bayesian context.

Ridge Regression (also known as Tikhonov Regularization) is a classical regularization technique widely used in Statistics and Machine Learning. In its classical form, Ridge Regression is essentially Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) Linear Regression with a tunable additive L2 norm penalty term embedded into the risk function. The invention of Ridge Regression was originally motivated as a solution for ill-posed least squares problems with severe or perfect collinearity in the covariates of the design matrix X (making the matrix from the inner product of the transpose of X and itself either severely unstable or non-invertible). Implementation of the Ridge Regression “regularizes” the mentioned non-invertible matrix, adjusting it to be invertible and providing a closed form solution for parameter estimates similar to OLS.

However, in modern times the Ridge Regression is most popularly leveraged as a general tool for empirical risk minimization in Statistical Learning and Machine Learning; i.e. purposely specifying biased statistical estimators in the interest of greatly reducing the variance (and thus improving efficiency) of said statistical estimators for prediction.

Note, the term “Ridge penalty” is often used today to refer to the embedding of a L2 penalty in the risk function of most any statistical model (examples: Logistic Regression, Neural Networks, etc). However, in this article, our use of the term “Ridge Regression” refers specifically to its classical definition (OLS with a tunable additive L2 norm penalty).

It turns out there is a connection between classical Ridge Regression and Bayesian Inference. One I find interesting and insightful. I hope the above is insightful. As I’ve mentioned in some of my previous pieces, it’s my opinion not enough folks take the time to go through these types of exercises. For me, this type of theory-based insight leaves me more comfortable using methods in practice. A personal goal of mine is to encourage others in the field to take a similar approach.
